pharm1: Aspirin is generally used to treat pain and fever in all regions of the body. Aspirin can prevent blood clots, which lead to heart attack and stroke. Aspirin does these by preventing the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes.
pharm2: Prostaglandins play a role in pain, inflammation and fever. Thromboxanes cause platelet cells in the blood to clump together and clot blood. Aspirin blocks the production of these substances by interfering with the activity of proteins known as COX (cyclo-oxygenase-enzyme). Prostaglandins protect the stomach lining and its inhibition can cause or worsen stomach ulcers. Blocking of thromboxanes can also lead to excessive bleeding.

quia et suscipit
suscipit recusandae consequuntur expedita et cum
reprehenderit molestiae ut ut quas totam
nostrum rerum est autem sunt rem eveniet architecto

pharm1: see Diclofenac
Paracetamol or acetaminophen can be used to treat pain and fever. The action of paracetamol is not fully understood at the time of this documentation.
pharm2: It has been proven to interfere with COX (cyclo-oxygenase-enzyme) in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) only which makes it a weak anti-inflammatory agent. COX is a protein that aids in the production of prostaglandins, involved in pain and fever.

pharm1: Acetazolamide interferes with carbonic anhydrase, a protein that helps regulate the acid-base balance of the body. In the kidney, CA helps maintain body pH by causing retention of basic molecules and urination of acidic molecules. Acetazolamide causes the excretion of basic molecules. This causes loss of body fluids and increased blood acidity.
pharm2: This makes it helpful in excreting excess water and relieving pressure associated with glaucoma, post-operative intra-ocular pressure, intra-cranial pressure, heart failure and edema. The increase in acid levels causes a perception of high carbon dioxide levels and the body compensates with deep and heavy breathing making it helpful in managing mountain sickness.
